Cool, thanks! Yeah, I'm not sure about "Deactivate" vs. "Confirm", so thanks for making that change separately.

We've generally been moving in the policy direction of using "Confirm" ~everywhere for confirmation dialogs rather than having a range of different labels of varying quality. You can see the remaining exceptions where we override this default with this command:

$ git grep html_submit_button
static/js/confirm_dialog.js:        html_submit_button: $t_html({defaultMessage: "Confirm"}),
static/js/deprecated_feature_notice.js:            html_submit_button: $t_html({defaultMessage: "Got it"}),
static/js/dialog_widget.js:    // * html_submit_button: Submit button text.
static/js/dialog_widget.js:    const html_submit_button = conf.html_submit_button || $t_html({defaultMessage: "Save changes"});
static/js/dialog_widget.js:        html_submit_button,
static/js/message_edit_history.js:        html_submit_button: $t_html({defaultMessage: "Close"}),
static/js/settings_account.js:            html_submit_button: $t_html({defaultMessage: "Change"}),
static/js/settings_account.js:                html_submit_button: $t_html({defaultMessage: "Change"}),
static/js/settings_display.js:        html_submit_button: $t_html({defaultMessage: "Close"}),
static/js/settings_realm_domains.js:        html_submit_button: $t_html({defaultMessage: "Close"}),
static/js/settings_user_groups.js:        html_submit_button: $t_html({defaultMessage: "Save"}),
static/js/stream_popover.js:        html_submit_button: $t_html({defaultMessage: "Confirm"}),
static/js/user_status_ui.js:        html_submit_button: $t_html({defaultMessage: "Save"}),
static/templates/dialog_widget.hbs:                    <span>{{{ html_submit_button }}}</span>

This goes against most UI guidelines I’ve seen. Apple:

Avoid using OK as the default button title unless the alert is purely informational. The meaning of “OK” can be unclear even in alerts that ask people to confirm that they want to do something. For example, does “OK” mean “OK, I want to complete the action” or “OK, I now understand the negative results my action would have caused”? A specific button title like “Erase,” “Convert,” “Clear,” or “Delete” helps people understand the action they’re taking.
Maybe we can aim for a handful of labels with clear guidelines for when to use them? I think what we'd really like to avoid is random variation.

A couple of questions about the above code:

  1. What does this part affect?
    static/js/dialog_widget.js: const html_submit_button = conf.html_submit_button || $t_html({defaultMessage: "Save changes"});

  2. Is there a reason this one is specified even though it's the same as the default?

static/js/stream_popover.js: html_submit_button: $t_html({defaultMessage: "Confirm"}),
2: Likely no.
1: That is the default for more complex modals like editing a user.
And I guess there are other buttons that aren't included in the list above but we should still think about (e.g. Save/Cancel for editing a message).
Sure, this is just modals.
Is there a way to get a more complete list, or not really?
You can browse translations.json.

OK, so these seem to be some reasonable rules we're currently using and/or discussed above:

  • Confirm: Default
  • Add: Add a thing.
    • "Add new user group" should be changed to use "Add"
  • Save changes: Modify a thing
  • Close: Used to close a dialog that has no overall action (e.g. informational only).

I'm not so sure about our use of "Save" in a couple of places I'm familiar with:

Screen-Shot-2022-07-26-at-10.51.17-PM.png
Screen-Shot-2022-07-26-at-10.51.58-PM.png

How do folks feel about these? Perhaps "Confirm" would be fine for the emoji status picker, and "Save changes" might be better for message moving/editing.
The argument Anders Kaseorg makes above for using "Deactivate" for deactivation modals make sense to me; I'd be happy to add that to the list.

Alya Abbott said:

How do folks feel about these? Perhaps "Confirm" would be fine for the emoji status picker, and "Save changes" might be better for message moving/editing.

Both of the above suggestions make sense to me, as well as adding "Deactivate" for deactivation modals to the list of rules.

I'm not sure about "Add" vs. "Create" for modals to create a new thing; somehow "Add" feels a bit wrong to me for the button action.

One could also just go with "Save" for the button label in a creation context, like the status -- I feel like that's a pretty common pattern I've seen in other apps.
Labels like "Add/Create a user group" are more appropriate for the modal's heading than the button, in my view.
So I'd propose "Confirm/Close/Save changes/Save/Deactivate" as the set of options.
Hmm, "Save" seems odd to me both for "Add/Create X" modals, as well as "Set X" above. It sounds more like you're saving some state, rather than taking the main action of the modal.

Maybe worth looking at how some other products handle this sort of thing. The "Set status" modal is a bit weird, since it's the same one for changing your status or adding one when you don't have one, and it's possible we want to have the title (but nothing else) vary for those -- I think "Add a status" or "Change your status" are both things that feel like "Save" would be what I'd usually see to commit a change.

In the message editing UI, since we are removing the notices about what you can/can't do to a message (e.g., "Topic editing only"), should we move the Save/Cancel buttons to the right and style them like the buttons in our modals?
Yes, I think so. That would also allow us to have the design better match the compose box arrangement of icons.
